utterances: And then just, I sort of took on the role of a parent.
And an Afghan colleague and I, we began, you know, we tutored them and I made sure they did their homework.
And we really gave them expectations.
They got excited.
They began to have dreams, they started talking about the things that they wanted to do.
And then four months later, I left.
And I told them I'd come back, but I really didn't believe it at that time.
I didn't know what was in store for me in terms of other assignments and I always felt that I had given them expectations, but had left them no place to go.

And the more I thought about it, the more I felt that my relationship with the boys was, in a sense, a metaphor for the world's relationship with Afghanistan - we go in, we promise a lot and then we leave.
And last summer, last spring when the Taliban was making inroads very close to Kabul, I decided I needed to go back and find the boys.

There's a point during your search for them, you're carrying pictures that are obviously four years old at that point, of the boys and trying to locate one and you talked to a man who says why these boys?

Right, yeah.

I need help.

It was.
Kabul is somewhat of an illusion.
On the surface, there's all sorts of construction going on.
They have malls now.
You can buy widescreen TVs.

But beneath the surface there's a real anger because again, to use the metaphor, you know, as the boys had expectations of me, so the country had expectations of the United States and the international coalition and five years later or six years later, many people feel their life hasn't improved.
And they see, you know, people drive around in SUVs.

They see the large houses that aid agencies rent and that private security firms rent, and they just see a great disparity between the westerners who were there who they feel should be helping them and what they feel is the result of their presence, which many people just feel isn't that much.

The drivers, regarded as security risks, are asked to remain outside.
They can't come inside.
Right.
And that, you see that a lot and, you know, it's just, it's the awkward situation of working with people who in many instances, you don't know who is friend or foe.
And as a result, it may not be the intent, but you give the impression of an occupation.

And that's what my colleague said to me, that when you tell Afghan people they can't walk down particular streets where there are western embassies or western businesses, or you can't go into a particular restaurant because it's for westerners and security, it gives the impression that the coalition is occupying the country, which then takes away the veneer that they're there really to help rebuild and then turn the country over.

On a newly paved highway, so there is some reconstruction going on.
Oh, absolutely.
You can see improvements, but as one international aid worker told me, said the successes are not proportional to the amount of money pouring into the country.
So the roads from Kabul to Jalalabad is paved and it's wonderful.
It takes about two hours now, whereas before, it took five to six hours.

But those kinds of improvements aren't, you don't see them consistently and even when there's an improvement, as we show in the story, you might be able to get from one place or another, but it's very dangerous because of the insurgency.

You don't - there aren't alternatives for them to pursue, you get very angry.

And that anger is widespread and so yes, people were pretty candid with me about either suggesting the boys get guns or that they probably have already joined the insurgency and I shouldn't bother looking for them.
